The Royally insulting interview

19/11/2019

After watching Prince Andrew &amp; the Epstein Scandal: The Newsnight Interview on BBC iPlayer the morning after it had aired on BBC Two on 16th November, I was left astounded.

Image by Northern Ireland Office

By Izzy Hall

After watching Prince Andrew & the Epstein Scandal: The Newsnight Interview on BBC iPlayer the morning after it had aired on BBC Two on 16th November, I was left astounded.

The excruciating interview comes months after Jeffrey Epstein died in prison in New York where he was awaiting trial on charges of sexual abuse and trafficking of dozens of underage girls, facing up to 45 years in prison. Police initially investigated Epstein in 2005 after parents of a 14-year-old girl filed a complaint that their daughter had been molested by Epstein at his Palm Beach home. Florida prosecutors accused Epstein of paying girls under the age of 18, the age of consent in the US, to perform sex acts at his various homes. A controversial deal was then reached in 2008 in which Epstein pleaded guilty to the lesser charge of procuring a minor for prostitution. Epstein received an 18-month sentence but was released on probation after serving just 13 months. In December 2010, mere months after Epsteinâ€™s release, Prince Andrew stayed with him in New York for an alleged four days and the News of the World published a photograph of the two men walking together in Central Park during this visit.

In 2015, Virginia Roberts (now Virginia Guiffre) alleged in a Florida court that she had been forced to have sex with Prince Andrew on three occasions. After the judge ruled the details were unnecessary to the case as they were impertinent to the central claim, they were struck from the court records. A ruling was not made on the truth of these claims. For his part, Prince Andrew has consistently denied any allegations made against him and this interview provided another opportunity for him to do so. But the overwhelming impression was one of alarmingly little, if any remorse.

When interviewer Emily Maitlis asked the Duke of York â€œWhy were you staying with a convicted sex offender?â€, he answered, â€œNow I went there with the sole purpose of saying to him that because he had been convicted it was inappropriate for us to be seen togetherâ€¦I felt that doing it over the phone was the chickenâ€™s way of doing it, I had to go see him and talk to himâ€¦I said, â€œLook, because of what has happened, I donâ€™t think it is appropriate that we should remain in contactâ€â€¦I never had any contact with him from that day forwardâ€¦And I saidâ€¦â€œbut with all the attendant scrutiny on me, then I donâ€™t think it is a wise thing to doâ€. This meeting was not a means of expressing his abhorrence at Epsteinâ€™s crimes but â€œsolelyâ€ concerned with his reputation. He did not state that he wished to dissolve their friendship due to moral or ethical reasons but simply because it was no longer â€œappropriateâ€ or â€œwiseâ€ given the â€œscrutinyâ€ that he was facing. His poorly chosen words suggest that they could no longer remain in contact because he had been â€œconvictedâ€; not because of what he had done but because he had been caught doing it.

The feelings of Epsteinâ€™s victims were never discussed by Prince Andrew at any point during the interview. In fact, although he utilised plenty of time categorically denying the allegations made against him, providing defences ranging from faked photographs to a Woking Pizza Express, he never showed any remorse over his friendship with Epstein. In response to Maitlis asking point-blank, â€œDo you regret the whole friendship with Epstein?â€, he responded, â€œNow, still not. The reason being that the people that I met and the opportunities that I was given to learn, either by him or because of him, were actually very usefulâ€. At this point, I was left fuming, digging my nails in the palms of my fists. Here is a man born a Prince, sitting in Buckingham Palace, expressing no regret in his continued relationship with an undisputed serial abuser of young women and children, because of the â€œopportunitiesâ€ it offered him. Can he be that unaware of what he is saying? He believes that his relationship with a convicted sex offender is not regrettable, that Epstein may have trafficked underage girls but that does not have any bearing on his feelings towards his friendship with him. If I discovered someone in my life was a paedophile, I would be wrecked with guilt over my association with them regardless of what â€œopportunitiesâ€ their friendship may have offered me, in fact, I would be stick to my stomach knowing that I had benefitted from someone who was abusing so many others.

Maitlis later offered Prince Andrew another chance in expressing remorse, one he had not earned by now, asking, â€œI wonder if you have any sense now of guilt, regret or shame about any of your behaviour and your friendship with Epsteinâ€ to which he answered characteristically obliviously, â€œAs far as my association with him was concerned, it had some seriously beneficial outcomes in areas that have nothing to do with what I would describe as what we are talking about todayâ€¦Do I regret the fact that he has quite obviously conducted himself in a manner unbecoming? Yesâ€. Maitlis immediately responded â€œUnbecoming? He was a sex offenderâ€, her face as dumbfounded as I was angry. The Duke of York quickly replied â€œYeah, Iâ€™m sorry, Iâ€™m being politeâ€, once again failing to recognise the faults of his words. Complimenting himself as â€œpoliteâ€, Prince Andrew acknowledges a self-proclaimed respectfulness rather than apologising for insultingly downplaying such serious crimes as â€œa manner unbecomingâ€. Epstein was not improper, he was amoral.

This sort of behaviour was also present earlier on when Maitlis interrogated his decision to stay at the house of a convicted sex offender for a reported four days following his so-called termination of their friendship. Prince Andrew justified his decision saying, â€œIt was a convenient place to stayâ€¦At the end of the day, with the benefit of all the hindsight that one could have, it was definitely the wrong thing to do. But at the time, I felt it was the honourable and right thing to do. And I admit fully that my judgment was probably coloured by my tendency to be too honourableâ€. What on earth seemed honourable and right about staying in the house belonging to such a man? If he was so intent on ending their relationship, why would he choose to stay there? Were his staff, those he repeatedly mentioned throughout the interview, not able to find other suitable accommodation for a member of the Royal family in the whole of New York?

In a deeply unsettling moment of seeming admiration, Prince Andrew observed that Epstein â€œhad the most extraordinary ability to bring extraordinary people togetherâ€¦It was a cosmopolitan group of what I would describe as US eminenceâ€. This reeks of the unacceptable practice of attaching brilliance to predators in the hopes of negating their heinous crimes. The Duke of Yorkâ€™s judgment was not coloured by his â€œtendency to be too honourableâ€, it was simply â€œconvenientâ€ to ignore Epsteinâ€™s criminal behaviour in order to further himself. But I suspect this interview will justifiably damage the Princeâ€™s reputation, exposing his dishonourable views, his rather â€œchickenâ€™s wayâ€ of failing to address the severity of Epsteinâ€™s crimes and his disturbing lack of remorse.
